nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates and IAMs (notably DICE) severely underestimate economic damages from climate change and are unsuitable for assessing climate risks or guiding policy
A primary cause of underestimation is systematic neglect or misrepresentation of climate tipping points and tipping cascades in economic damage estimates

Economists commonly assume only weather-exposed sectors are vulnerable and therefore omit or downweight impacts on much of the economy (manufacturing, services, government), producing trivial aggregate damages

Common empirical methods are flawed: using spatial cross-sectional relationships between current temperature and income as proxies for temporal global warming (the 'statistical' method) is invalid and misleads damage estimates

Other methodological issues include enumerative omission of indirect and economy-wide channels, reliance on small expert surveys with diverging views, use of CGE assumptions that dampen damages via market adaptation, and shared data/calibration that propagates errors across IAMs

The DICE model architecture and common IAM design assumptions (representative agent Ramsey framework, Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous TFP and full employment) make them incapable of generating economic collapse regardless of damage severity

Scientific literature documents multiple tipping elements likely to be triggered this century (Arctic sea-ice, Greenland ice sheet, etc.) and tipping cascades that amplify damages and risk non-linear outcomes
Including realistic tipping point probabilities in DICE-style models greatly increases estimated damages and social cost of carbon (e.g., factors >8 in cited studies)

Three rebuttals to the 'only weather-exposed sectors matter' assumption: (a) extreme events (fires, floods) affect factories/offices; (b) lethal heat/humidity makes regions uninhabitable so indoor production halts; (c) climate affects availability and cost of essential environmental inputs (energy, agriculture, minerals)
Therefore omitting manufacturing/services or treating them as insulated yields severely biased low aggregate damage estimates

Spatial cross-section fits (regional temperature vs current output) explain little variance, fail to account for trade, historical adaptation, topsoil and biophysical constraints, and cannot capture emergent climates or tipping-driven regime changes

Nordhaus expert elicitation of 19 respondents produced wide, divergent damage estimates with scientists predicting much larger damages than many economists, yet the median/mean small estimates dominated policy citation

CGE and enumerative approaches often feed partial-equilibrium sectoral estimates into equilibrium adaptation assumptions, which systematically reduce projected damages and ignore catastrophic/climate-system non-linearities

DICE and Ramsey-based IAMs impose saddle-path stability and representative-agent optimization with exogenous productivity and full employment, implying instantaneous 'jumps' in control variables and excluding non-equilibrium collapse dynamics

Sensitivity simulations of DICE with much larger quadratic damage coefficients show the model resists collapse: economies recover after deep contractions, mitigation jumps to corner solutions, capital-output and consumption dip to extreme but then rebound, and only beyond an extreme damage threshold does numerical infeasibility occur

Because DICE cannot represent systemic collapse or many indirect channels of damage, calibrating policy to its outputs (including social cost of carbon estimates) leads to under-protective policy recommendations
